scenes.plot_segment: Meredith Grey narrates about intimacy, describing it as something everyone wants but also fears, calling it hard to live with and impossible to live without. She reflects on the complications of relatives, romance, and roommates. Early in the morning at Meredith’s house, Izzie Stevens asks if someone is using her toothbrush, highlighting the awkwardness of sharing personal space. Meredith’s narration continues as Izzie greets their cat and George O’Malley complains about the lack of privacy, mentioning that the women walk around in their underwear while he’s naked in the shower. Izzie asks George to buy tampons, but he refuses, insisting he doesn’t buy “girl products.” Meredith adds tampons to the shopping list and Izzie reminds George it’s his turn to shop. George protests, but Izzie and Meredith dismiss his complaints, with Izzie teasing George by flaunting her underwear. The roommates’ interactions underscore the blurred boundaries and discomforts of living together, while Meredith’s narration muses on the unavoidable intimacy of their daily lives.

Meredith Grey narrates about the complexities of intimacy, reflecting on how it is both sought after and feared, and how living with others brings unavoidable complications. Early in the morning at Meredith’s house, Izzie Stevens asks if someone is using her toothbrush, while George O’Malley complains about the lack of privacy, mentioning that the women walk around in their underwear and that he was naked in the shower. Izzie greets the house cat and asks George to buy tampons, but he refuses, saying he doesn’t buy “girl products.” Izzie is unfazed by the nudity and tells George to get used to it. Meredith adds tampons to the shopping list, and Izzie reminds George it’s his turn to shop. George protests, but Izzie and Meredith dismiss his complaints, with Izzie teasing him by flaunting her underwear. The roommates’ awkward morning routine highlights the challenges of sharing a house and navigating personal boundaries.

Cristina Yang enters Elizabeth Fallon’s hospital room early in the morning and abruptly wakes her. Fallon, a former scrub nurse now hospitalized with pancreatic cancer, immediately recognizes Cristina’s eagerness and calls out her attempt to impress Dr. Burke and secure a spot in the upcoming Whipple procedure. Cristina introduces herself, but Fallon insists on being addressed as “Nurse Fallon” and pointedly calls Cristina “Christina,” correcting her. After their tense exchange, Cristina moves on to check on Mr. Humphrey, who is also a patient on her pre-rounds. Izzie Stevens joins her and introduces herself to Mr. Humphrey, but he refuses to let Izzie examine him, recognizing her from her past as a lingerie model and insisting he only wants to be seen by Dr. Bailey or Dr. Victor. Mr. Humphrey asks Izzie to leave, making her visibly uncomfortable, while Cristina continues with her patient assessments.

Early in the morning at Meredith Grey’s house, George O’Malley complains about the lack of privacy, frustrated that Izzie Stevens and Meredith walk around in their underwear while he’s naked in the shower. Izzie, unfazed, asks George to buy tampons, but he refuses, insisting he doesn’t buy “girl products.” Meredith adds tampons to the shopping list, reminding George it’s his turn to shop. Izzie teases George by flaunting her underwear, and Meredith insists that house rules are necessary to set boundaries. Cristina Yang joins the conversation and pointedly asks George if he has a crush on Izzie, which he denies, clarifying that he’s interested in someone else. Their discussion is cut short when Dr. Miranda Bailey calls, instructing Meredith and George to report to trauma for a case involving Dr. Derek Shepherd.

Jorge Cruz arrives in the trauma bay after accidentally shooting seven nails into his skull with a nail gun. He is conscious but has lost his vision. Meredith Grey, George O'Malley, and Alex Karev assist Dr. Derek Shepherd as they assess Jorge’s condition and discuss pain management, infection risk, and the need for imaging. With the CT scanner down and MRI ruled out due to the metal in Jorge’s head, Dr. Shepherd decides to use X-rays and a C-Arm to evaluate the injuries. Jorge’s wife, Sona, arrives, visibly upset and frustrated with Jorge for using the nail gun, while his partner Javi shares that Jorge has recently experienced headaches and vision problems. Dr. Shepherd instructs the interns to research similar nail gun injuries and gather more information to help guide treatment.

Cristina Yang presents Elizabeth Fallon’s case to Dr. Preston Burke, emphasizing her interest in assisting with Fallon’s potential Whipple procedure for pancreatic cancer. Burke recognizes Cristina’s ambition but informs her that he had intended to assign Fallon’s case to Meredith Grey, since Fallon was Ellis Grey’s scrub nurse for 18 years but never met Meredith. Liz, the current scrub nurse, comments on Cristina’s eagerness and notes Meredith’s connection to Ellis Grey. Despite Cristina’s efforts, Burke assigns Meredith to Fallon’s case and redirects Cristina to another patient. Cristina is instructed to take Fallon for an MRI after her bloodwork is completed. Meanwhile, the surgical interns—Cristina, Meredith, Izzie Stevens, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev—discuss the unusual trauma case involving Jorge Cruz and speculate about the possibility of a Whipple procedure for Fallon, with Cristina expressing her frustration at being passed over for the case.

George O'Malley interviews Jorge Cruz about his medical history while Sona, Jorge’s wife, describes his recent headaches and episodes of lightheadedness. Sona expresses frustration over Jorge’s use of the nail gun, and Jorge’s partner Javi adds details about Jorge’s symptoms leading up to the accident. Meredith Grey, Alex Karev, Cristina Yang, and Izzie Stevens join George to discuss possible causes for Jorge’s accident, including the possibility of a brain tumor. Dr. Derek Shepherd instructs the interns to prioritize getting Jorge safely through surgery before investigating underlying causes. The interns report their research on nail gun injuries, noting there are 23 documented cases, and discuss the risks involved in removing the nails from Jorge’s skull.

Izzie Stevens is assigned to assist with Mr. Humphrey’s prostate biopsy, but Mr. Humphrey refuses to let her participate after recognizing her from a lingerie modeling ad. He demands another doctor, making Izzie visibly uncomfortable and undermining her authority as a physician. Dr. Miranda Bailey insists that Izzie must do her job regardless of the patient’s attitude and tells her to act like a doctor. Upset but determined, Izzie continues with her duties. Later, Cristina Yang finds Izzie hiding in the hallway and confronts her, urging her to stop letting the situation affect her performance. Izzie vents her frustration to Cristina and Meredith Grey, who tease her about her modeling past but also encourage her to stand her ground. Dr. Bailey instructs Izzie to biopsy the tissue samples from Mr. Humphrey and tells her she will be expected to participate in surgery if the results are positive, reinforcing that she belongs in the OR as much as any other intern.

In the operating room, Dr. Derek Shepherd leads the surgical team as they prepare to remove the seven nails embedded in Jorge Cruz’s skull. Meredith Grey, George O’Malley, and Dr. Miranda Bailey assist, while Derek explains the significant risks involved, including the possibility of fatal bleeding or permanent brain damage. Meredith summarizes the dangers for the team, demonstrating her understanding. Dr. Bailey emphasizes the need for precision, instructing the interns to remove each nail at the exact angle it entered to avoid further injury. Alex Karev and Cristina Yang observe, with Alex commenting on the X-rays and Cristina discussing the difficulty of getting assigned to a Whipple procedure. As the surgery progresses, Derek carefully extracts each nail, and the team monitors for signs of bleeding or neurological decline. Jorge’s wife, Sona, anxiously waits outside, supported by Jorge’s partner Javi. The team successfully removes all the nails without causing additional bleeding. Derek decides to delay ordering an MRI until Jorge stabilizes, prioritizing his immediate recovery and minimizing further risk.

Cristina Yang approaches Dr. Preston Burke to discuss scheduling the Whipple procedure for Elizabeth Fallon, the former scrub nurse now admitted with pancreatic cancer. Cristina points out Fallon’s worsening lab results and increasing jaundice, expressing concern about delaying surgery. Dr. Burke responds that he wants to review Fallon’s biopsy and overnight labs before making any decisions, emphasizing the need for caution. He instructs Cristina to stay with Fallon and keep a close eye on her condition. Cristina, eager to assist in the surgery and frustrated by the lack of a definitive plan, reluctantly agrees and confirms she is on call. As Burke leaves, Cristina’s impatience is evident, but she remains at Fallon’s bedside, determined to be involved in her care.

Meredith Grey visits her mother, Ellis Grey, at the nursing home and shows her old family photos, gently encouraging Ellis to remember their family. Ellis looks at the photos but does not recognize her husband or daughter, showing no recollection of her past. Meredith mentions seeing Liz Fallon at the hospital, prompting Ellis to recall Fallon fondly and ask if she is still working as a scrub nurse. Meredith quietly confirms, masking the truth about Ellis’s condition and her own feelings about her mother’s fading memory.

Early in the morning at Meredith’s house, Izzie greets the cat and complains about someone using her toothbrush, prompting Meredith to deflect. George, frustrated by the lack of privacy, protests about Izzie and Meredith walking around in their underwear while he’s in the shower. Izzie asks George to buy tampons, but he refuses, insisting he doesn’t buy “girl products.” Meredith adds tampons to the shopping list and reminds George it’s his turn to shop. Izzie and Meredith are unfazed by George’s discomfort, with Izzie teasing him by flaunting her underwear and telling him to get used to living with women. George protests that he’s not their sister, but the women dismiss his complaints and continue with their morning routine.

Early in the morning at Meredith’s house, Izzie greets the cat and asks if someone has been using her toothbrush, while George complains about the lack of privacy, referencing the women walking around in their underwear and his discomfort with the living situation. Izzie tells George to get used to it and asks him to buy tampons, but he refuses, insisting he doesn’t buy “girl products.” Meredith adds tampons to the shopping list, and Izzie reminds George it’s his turn to shop. George protests, but Izzie and Meredith dismiss his complaints, with Izzie teasing George by flaunting her underwear as she heads to the bathroom. The roommates’ banter highlights the awkwardness and lack of boundaries in their shared home.

Cristina Yang is abruptly scolded by Nurse Elizabeth Fallon after waking her up too early during pre-rounds. Fallon, annoyed, questions Cristina about her personal life, pointedly asking if she has a boyfriend, girlfriend, pet, or family. Cristina, exhausted from being on call, admits that all she has is a bed. Fallon, recognizing Cristina’s ambition and isolation, tells her that as surgeons, their lives are defined by the hospital and warns her not to feel sorry for herself, emphasizing that this demanding lifestyle is the reality they have chosen.

In the locker room at Seattle Grace, Alex Karev mocks Izzie Stevens by calling her “Dr. Model” and referencing her past as a lingerie model, while George O’Malley and Cristina Yang look on. Alex and some of the other interns tease Izzie about a lingerie ad she appeared in, making crude jokes and questioning her credibility as a doctor. Izzie, frustrated but composed, responds by stripping down to her bra and underwear in front of them, confronting their judgment head-on. She explains that her modeling work paid off her medical school loans and asserts that her past doesn’t make her any less of a doctor. The other interns are silenced and visibly uncomfortable, while Izzie stands her ground, forcing them to reconsider their assumptions about her.

Izzie Stevens confronts Mr. Humphrey in his hospital room about his refusal to let her participate in his care. She firmly asserts her qualifications as a doctor and insists that she deserves respect regardless of her past as a lingerie model. Mr. Humphrey admits he recognized Izzie from her modeling photos and confesses that he has fantasized about her, which makes him uncomfortable with her involvement in his prostate cancer surgery. He explains that he doesn’t want Izzie to witness what he perceives as his emasculation during the procedure. Izzie listens empathetically, acknowledges his feelings, and reassures him of her professionalism and commitment to his care.

Cristina Yang approaches Dr. Burke to press him about scheduling the Whipple procedure for Elizabeth Fallon, arguing that Fallon’s condition is worsening and she urgently needs surgical intervention. Burke responds that he is still waiting for the final biopsy results before making a decision. Frustrated, Cristina accuses Burke of never intending to operate and treating Fallon as if she is only in the hospital to die rather than to be helped. Burke insists he will review the labs, but Cristina’s concern for Fallon’s fate and her impatience with Burke’s caution are clear in their tense exchange.

The MRI confirms that Jorge Cruz has a tumor located in the midline of his hypothalamus. Dr. Derek Shepherd explains the prognosis to Jorge and his wife, Sona: surgical removal of most of the tumor could extend Jorge’s life by five to ten years but carries significant risks, including potential loss of memory and changes to his personality; alternatively, focused radiation is less invasive but would likely offer only three to five more years. Sona is visibly distressed, struggling with the weight of the decision, while Jorge listens quietly as Dr. Shepherd outlines the difficult choices ahead. Meredith Grey and Cristina Yang observe the conversation, recognizing the emotional toll on the couple as they process the life-altering options before them.

Meredith Grey sits with Elizabeth Fallon, who asks about Ellis Grey’s whereabouts. Meredith hesitates, then admits the truth: Ellis has early-onset Alzheimer’s and is living in a nursing home, with Meredith as her only visitor. Fallon processes the news, reflecting on Ellis’s relentless work ethic and dedication to the hospital. She bluntly calls Ellis a “bitch,” but acknowledges that her commitment helped build the hospital’s reputation. Meredith listens quietly as Fallon expresses a mix of respect and criticism for Ellis, and the two women share a moment of understanding about the burdens and sacrifices of their profession.

In the hospital break room, Meredith Grey, Cristina Yang, Izzie Stevens, George O’Malley, and Alex Karev discuss Elizabeth Fallon’s case, questioning whether the hospital is simply where she will die and debating if aggressive intervention is always the right choice. Cristina argues for the Whipple procedure, while Meredith voices doubts about whether Fallon ever intended to have surgery. The interns tease each other about their abilities and insecurities—Alex mocks Izzie by calling her “Dr. Model,” referencing her past as a lingerie model, and Cristina jokes that if she looked like Izzie, she’d walk around naked all the time. Izzie laughs it off, insisting her looks are just makeup and retouching. The group’s banter highlights their anxieties about their skills and the emotional toll of caring for dying patients, as well as the personal insecurities that come with working so closely together.

In the hallway outside the OR, Dr. Miranda Bailey confronts Izzie Stevens for not answering her page, sharply reminding her of the importance of being reachable. Izzie, visibly upset, vents her frustration about being called “Dr. Bethany Whisperer” and feeling humiliated by Mr. Humphrey’s refusal to let her participate in his surgery because of her modeling past. She feels unwelcome in the operating room and questions her place on the team. Bailey, firm but empathetic, tells Izzie that Mr. Humphrey’s real concern is his fear and desire to be saved, not her past or appearance. Bailey makes it clear that it’s Izzie’s decision whether to let the patient’s attitude keep her from doing her job, emphasizing that being a doctor means showing up for patients even when it’s uncomfortable.

Jorge Cruz and his wife Sona meet with Dr. Shepherd and Dr. Bailey to discuss treatment options after discovering Jorge has a hypothalamic tumor. Dr. Shepherd explains the risks: removing the tumor surgically could save Jorge’s life but may cause permanent memory loss, while radiation is less invasive but offers only a few more years to live. Sona struggles with the decision, worried about the toll on their family, but ultimately supports Jorge’s choice, even if it means years of hardship. Meanwhile, Cristina Yang realizes that Dr. Burke and the surgical team never intended to operate on Elizabeth Fallon, the former scrub nurse. Meredith Grey confronts Fallon about this, and Fallon admits she knew the odds were bad and didn’t want to put herself or the team through a futile surgery. Suddenly, Fallon’s condition deteriorates. Cristina and the team rush in and attempt to resuscitate her, but Dr. Bailey reminds them that Fallon is DNR. Cristina is forced to stop CPR, and Fallon dies as the team stands by, respecting her wishes.

In the operating room, Dr. Victor begins Mr. Humphrey’s prostatectomy with Dr. Miranda Bailey and Izzie Stevens assisting. As Dr. Victor prepares to proceed quickly, Izzie speaks up, reminding the team that Mr. Humphrey specifically requested a nerve-sparing procedure to preserve his sexual function, even though it will make the surgery more complex and time-consuming. Dr. Victor is dismissive, arguing that the patient’s age makes it unnecessary, but Bailey firmly insists they honor the patient’s wishes. Izzie stands her ground, advocating for Mr. Humphrey’s right to quality of life, and Bailey backs her up, overruling Dr. Victor’s reluctance. The team adjusts their approach, committing to the nerve-sparing technique as Izzie and Bailey work together to ensure the patient’s preferences are respected.

Meredith Grey narrates about the complexities of intimacy, describing it as something everyone wants but also fears, and reflecting on the challenges of living with relatives, romance, and roommates. Early in the morning at the shared house, Izzie Stevens tries to get Meredith’s attention and asks if someone is using her toothbrush, highlighting the awkwardness of their living situation. Izzie greets the house cat, and George O’Malley complains about the lack of privacy, mentioning that the women parade around in their underwear while he’s naked in the shower. Izzie asks George to buy tampons, but he refuses, insisting he doesn’t buy “girl products.” Meredith adds tampons to the shopping list, and Izzie reminds George it’s his turn to shop. George protests, but Izzie and Meredith dismiss his complaints, and Izzie teases George by flaunting her underwear. Meredith’s narration continues, musing on the inescapable aspects of life and the things people would rather not know.

After Mr. Humphrey’s surgery, Izzie Stevens and Miranda Bailey discuss the outcome in the hospital corridor. Bailey jokes that Mr. Humphrey will now think of Izzie every time he gets an erection, lightening the mood after the tense procedure. Meredith Grey’s narration resumes, reflecting on the complexities of intimacy and the necessity of setting personal boundaries. Later, at home, Meredith tells Izzie and George O’Malley not to use her toothbrush. Izzie assures Meredith she hasn’t used it, and the roommates exchange good nights, settling in for the evening as Meredith’s voiceover concludes about the importance of making one’s own rules for intimacy.
